issues.text: Whether section 56 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951 is unconstitutional?

anchor.surface_text: These petitions under article 32 of the Constitution challenge the constitutionality of some of the provisions of the Bombay Police Act, XXII of 1951,  which hereinafter will, be referred to as The Act , with special reference to section 56, as also of

issues.text: Whether the externment orders passed under section 56 against the petitioners are valid and legal?

anchor.surface_text: section 56, as also of the orders passed against them externing them under that section of the Act. In Petition No. 439 of 1955 Babubhai Dullabhbhai Bhandari is the petitioner and the District Magistrate of Thana, the Deputy Superintendent of Police and Sub-Divisional Police Officer, Bhivandi Division, Bhivandi, District Thana, and the State of Bombay are respondents 1, 2 and 3.

issues.text: Whether the petitioners were afforded adequate opportunity under section 59 read with section 56 to explain the allegations?

arguments.claim: Externment more injurious than detention in practice

anchor.surface_text: Externment might appear on the surface -not to be as serious an interference with personal liberty as detention. But in actual practice it may be productive of more serious injury to the person companycerned-or the rest of his family if he is the earning member.

holdings.text: Section 56 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951 is not unconstitutional

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid it must be held that section 56 of the Act is number unconstitutional -and that the orders passed against the petitioners are number invalid. These applications must stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay upholding similar provision; no need to re-examine constitutionality

holdings.text: The externment orders passed against the petitioners under section 56 are valid and not invalid

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid it must be held that section 56 of the Act is number unconstitutional -and that the orders passed against the petitioners are number invalid. These applications must stand dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure followed; authority satisfied on facts causing alarm and witness unwillingness; petitioners given opportunity to explain

holdings.text: Persons proceeded against under section 56 given adequate opportunity under section 59 by informing general nature of material allegations

anchor.surface_text: But before passing such orders the person proceeded against under section 56 has to be given an opportunity of explaining matters against him by adducing such evidence as he may tender after he has been informed in writing as to the general nature of the material allegations against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory requirement satisfied by notice of general nature; particulars of evidence not required; dealt with in related judgment

holdings.text: Section 56 does not require that each and every witness must be unwilling to give evidence in open court

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge did number mean to lay down, and we do number understand him as having laid down, that unless each and every witness is unwilling to give evidence in open companyrt, the provisions of section 56 are number available to the police.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words of section 56 do not support extreme interpretation; would make provision impossible to apply; distinguishes observations in Gurbachan Singh

holdings.text: Term 'witnesses' in section 56 includes members of police force and customs officers; no exclusion

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, the terms of the section do number justify any such restricted meaning being given to the word witness. Hence, in our opinion, there is numberjustification for the companytention that members of the police force and employees and officers of the Customs Department must always companye in the open and give evidence against criminals or potential criminals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text does not restrict 'witness'; counsel of perfection not required; officer's satisfaction on unwillingness suffices regardless of witness class

holdings.text: Section 56 does not contravene Article 19 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: But I think it right to add that if the matter were res integra I should have felt difficulty in upholding the validity of section 56 b  of the Bombay Police Act, 1951  Bombay Act XXII of 1951  in so far as it did number demarcate the application thereof to the more serious classes of offences falling within the specified Chapters

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter; lacks limits on offences and review mechanism; externment potentially more injurious than detention; proportionality concerns

precedents.citation: Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay 1 as follows- The law is certainly an extraordinary, one and has been made only to meet those exceptional cases where numberwitnesses for fear of violence to their person or property are willing to depose publicly against certain bad characters whose presence-in certain areas companystitutes a menace to the safety of the public residing therein.

precedents.case_name: Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: The law is an extraordinary one made only to meet exceptional cases where witnesses are unwilling to depose publicly against bad characters due to fear of violence
precedents.cited_holding: The law is certainly an extraordinary, one and has been made only to meet those exceptional cases where no witnesses for fear of violence to their person or property are willing to depose publicly against certain bad characters whose presence in certain areas constitutes a menace to the safety of the public residing therein.
